message_1: A committee of 5 people needs to be formed from a group of 12 students. In how many ways can the committee be formed if two specific students must be included?
message_2:
Since two specific students must be included in the committee, we need to choose the remaining 3 members from the 10 remaining students (12 - 2 = 10). This is a combination problem, as the order of the members does not matter.

The number of ways to choose 3 members from a group of 10 is given by the combination formula:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n = 10 (total number of remaining students) and k = 3 (number of members to be chosen).

C(10, 3) = 10! / (3!(10-3)!)
= 10! / (3!7!)
= (10 × 9 × 8) / (3 × 2 × 1)
= 720 / 6
= 120

So, there are 120 ways to form the committee with the two specific students included.
